On Wednesday 13 September 2006 12:06, Gott wrote:
> Hello, 
> 
> I'm new to JUnit. Before I testet my code with System.out.println(),
> but in these days my code became more complex. I work with Eclipse-3.2
> and JUnit-4.1. 
> 
> First of all I have a problem with an error msg. 
> >>> java.lang.AssertError: expected: <1> but was: <2>
> Now I known that belongs to the number of contructors. But it was a
> very long way to get this solution. May it could be more infomational,
> please.  

As others have said, you can add a string message to the assertEquals
method.

But since you're using Eclipse, you can also run the JUnit tests inside
it, and then click on the entries in the JUnit pane to take you to the
line of the test that fails. Can't you?

-- 
Chris "falling further in" Dollin
The shortcuts are all full of people using them.
